Dear YES Prep Families,

As Hurricane Laura approaches the Gulf Coast, we are bracing for the severe weather and will not be holding virtual school tomorrow or Thursday. Online classes are also canceled tomorrow and Thursday for our partnership campuses in SBISD and Aldine ISD. We will follow guidance from local officials and keep you updated on plans for resuming classes Friday based on the storm’s impact.

We absolutely hate that we are having to cancel school just two days into the new year, but as always, the safety of the YES Prep community is our highest priority.

To those of you who lived through Katrina, Harvey, Ike, or any other traumatic storm and are reliving that trauma, we want you to know that you are in our thoughts and prayers during this difficult time.

Be strong and stay safe, and we’ll be back in touch soon.

Very proud of you ACE Marvels! Keep up the great work! 😊✨
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In honor of Pride Month, we asked our LGBT+ staff to share and describe a person they are inspired by. Carnetta Griffin, ACE Site Coordinator at YES Prep Northside, chose Audre Lorde. Here's what Griffin shared with us:

"Audre Lorde was a powerful Black lesbian woman fighting to bring more awareness to race, sexuality, class and the intersectionality of it all. She taught me that representation matters. Her work educates and reminds us that each person is multifaceted and we must celebrate all parts. Lorde’s work shows her dedication to representing all that she was and had been through. We must do the same in continuing to share our whole stories to show that we are not alone in this world.”
#PrideMonth

Every year in the heart of Houston's Third Ward, thousands of people gather in Emancipation Park for the annual Juneteenth celebration. And although we are staying home this year, the celebration continues.

Visit Emancipation Park Conservancy all day today to join the #WeAreJuneteenth celebration LIVE.

Emancipation Park, located in 3rd Ward, is the oldest park in Houston and one of the oldest across the state. It was created in 1872, when a group led by the Rev. Jack Yates, a former slave, raised $1,000 to buy 10 acres of land in Houston specifically to honor Juneteenth. ✊🏿✊🏽✊🏻

Black history IS American history.

Juneteenth (short for June nineteenth) celebrates the last day of slavery in the United States. Although the Emancipation Proclamation was issued by President Abraham Lincoln in 1863, it wasn’t until Union General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas on June 19, 1865 that the remaining slaves in Texas and the Confederate South were freed.

Starting tomorrow Friday, June 19, YES Prep will observe Juneteenth as an official annual YES Prep system-wide holiday. We invite you to celebrate this true freedom day with your family and friends. #juneteenth #freedomday

"James Baldwin consistently inspires and fuels me in my work, especially when I reflect on the additional challenge that comes with being both black and gay. Baldwin found a way to fight battles on an intellectual front that was so desperately in need of language to define experiences of the black community. He has recorded a painful narrative that continues, unfortunately, to be so incredibly relevant. It is his work that opened doors not only for racial minorities, but for those on the LGBT+ spectrum. PRIDE is a movement that is founded on our black brothers and sisters.”
#PrideMonth

In honor of Asian and Pacific Islander American (APIA) Heritage Month, we asked our APIA staff to share and describe a person that influenced them. Jon Ngo, IT Manager at the YES Prep Home Office, chose Yao Ming. Here's what Ngo had to say:

"I would say Yao Ming is someone who inspired me when I was younger. He was the first pick in the 2002 NBA draft and played for my home team Rockets. He came over not knowing any English and trying to fit in which reminded me of what my family had to go through. I was a young kid in school wanting to show that Asian people can play basketball too. Yao definitely showed that we can ball. He once said 'I think I'll stick to what I'm used to, my principle, and that is team No. 1 and individual No. 2.' I still live by that quote today. If we have a common goal, I'm always putting the team first."

#asianamericanpacificislanderheritagemonth

In honor of Asian and Pacific Islander American (APIA) Heritage Month, we asked our APIA teachers to share and describe a person that influenced them. Patrick Adre, English teacher at YES Prep Southeast, chose Jiro Ono. Here's what Adre shared with us:

"Jiro Ono (from the Netflix documentary, Jiro Dreams of Sushi) inspires me to recognize that falling in love with my work in teaching—and dedicating to get better continuously—is the key to success. He is someone who has dedicated his life to perfecting his craft, knowing that it can never be attained. As a teacher, I have learned that success and failure are merely steps to growth.”

#AsianPacificIslanderAmericanHeritageMonth

YES Prep students are not letting a pandemic stand in their way of college credit. More than 3,000 YES juniors and seniors continue their Advanced Placement coursework to prepare for the national exams they'll be taking in the next couple of weeks. Helping students prep for AP exams is one more way we #KeepYesPrepLearning. Our campuses may be closed, but teachers and staff are continuing their rigorous, college-ready support of every student, including seniors making final preparations for college—many while working to help their families during these trying times. GOOD LUCK to our AP students! 🙌

It's National School Breakfast Week! Our Child Nutrition team is celebrating by providing special menu items to students across our district and encouraging students to join us for breakfast.

Studies show that children who eat school breakfast are more likely to:
- Reach higher levels of achievement in reading and math
- Score higher on standardized tests
- Have better concentration and memory
- Be more alert and maintain a healthy weight

Follow us on Instagram at @yespreppublicschools to see how our campuses are celebrating #NSBW!

The United Negro College Fund (UNCF) STEM Scholars Program is an initiative designed to identify and provide scholarship and academic support for African-American high school students who aspire to earn STEM degrees and to pursue careers in STEM fields. This year UNCF is awarding 100 scholarships to first-time college freshmen in fall 2020. The UNCF will award up to $2,500 per academic year for freshmen and sophomores, $5,000 for juniors and seniors, and an additional $5,000 for students whose academic programs require a fifth year. A $5,000 stipend is also available based on a STEM-related project/internship of the student’s interest.

The deadline to apply is March 19. To apply and learn more about the benefits, click here: https://scholarships.uncf.org/Program/Details/1db5d542-4b11-42b1-adee-c142fc0dea43
#YESPrepBHM #ScholarshipAlert

YES Prep educators have, for more than 20 years, increased the number of students from underserved communities who graduate from college prepared to lead. Juan M. Venegas III, a software engineer and YES Prep North Central alum, is one of those students:

"As a mother who did not graduate college but wanted her child to have a better and brighter future, my mother knew that [YES Prep] was going to be a great decision ... Now that I have graduated and found employment in my degree of study, my younger brother and cousins are following suit. They are attending the same YES Prep charter school that I attended ... When it is their time to go to college, they will be ready. They will be ready thanks to the foundation YES Prep has given them, and thanks to the help I can give them as both an alum of their school and a recent college graduate."

Read Juan’s story in Education Post.
